{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3551693,"name":"Jason","username":"Jason81","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a9adbd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-09T03:58:30.282Z","cooked":"

Our team is at competition right now and experiencing an issue with running autos- specifically ones that work on the blue side but not on the red. With some very limited data logging to go off of, we presume this logic issue stems from how we configure our one limelight 4 that we use for localization as it gives some very absurd values for where the robot thinks it is. Here is the code for zeroing the robot called in autonomousInit

public void resetRobotGyroAndOrientation() {
Optional alliance = DriverStation.getAlliance();
if (alliance.isPresent()) {
if (alliance.get().equals(Alliance.Blue)) {
m_robotDrive.zeroHeading();
LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation(“limelight-gcc”, m_robotDrive.getAngle(), 0, 0, 0, 0, 0);
LimelightHelpers.setCameraPose_RobotSpace(“limelight-gcc”, -0.318, 0.177, 0.29, 0, 0, 180);
} else {
m_robotDrive.zeroHeading();
LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation(“limelight-gcc”, 180, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0);
LimelightHelpers.setCameraPose_RobotSpace(“limelight-gcc”, -0.318, 0.177, 0.29, 0, 0, 180);
}
}
}

We wrote this code to account for the fact that the robot starting on the blue alliance has different yaw values relative to the red alliance wall compared to starting on the red alliance, and since the camera space is robot relative both of those values should be the same. We are assuming there is some error in this logic as blue side works just fine but red side tends to freak out which is frustrating.

Any help would be appreciated, thanks!

We ended up talking to another team (Eastbots - 4795) who mentioned how our pose estimator worked with limelight could be wrong- specifically how we declared how much we relied on the rotation as shown:

 m_poseEstimator.setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(VecBuilder.fill(.5,.5, Units.degreesToRadians(20)));
          m_poseEstimator.addVisionMeasurement(
              mt1.pose,
              mt1.timestampSeconds);

We used to put 9999 in for the last value as limelight docs suggest, but changing that to 20 degrees seemed to fix the issue of our red side odometry freaking out- still unsure if this works in competition since we’re a little unwilling to miss out on a potential auto ranking point to test but here are some of our relevant branches in the meantime:

DriveSubsystem:Here
RobotContainer: Here
PoseEstimator: Here

Miller ","username":"BenjaminMiller","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/benjaminmiller/{size}/193876_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T19:43:45.999Z","cooked":"

Changing that value to 20 just mean your trusting the angle of limelight more. I would recommend against this. The root cause of your issue is that calling set robot orientation should be called routinely AND 0 on your pigeon should be facing specifically the Red Allience wall. My previous post showed the code to flip it

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T19:43:45.999Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":42,"readers_count":41,"score":13.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494829,"topic_slug":"question-on-limelight-flipping-logic","display_username":"Benjamin Miller ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":69118,"username":"Jason81","name":"Jason","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a9adbd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56130,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC-6420-Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/question-on-limelight-flipping-logic/494829/5","custom_user_title":"FRC-6420-Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3558136,"name":"Jason","username":"Jason81","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a9adbd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T04:26:16.742Z","cooked":"

The following code seemed to do the trick for us

Optional alliance = DriverStation.getAlliance();
if (alliance.isPresent()) {
if (alliance.get().equals(Alliance.Blue)) {
m_robotDrive.zeroHeading();
LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation(“limelight-gcc”, m_robotDrive.getAngle(), 0, 0, 0, 0, 0);
LimelightHelpers.setCameraPose_RobotSpace(“limelight-gcc”, -0.318, 0.177, 0.29, 0, 6, 180);
} else {
m_robotDrive.zeroHeading();
LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation(“limelight-gcc”, m_robotDrive.getAngle() + 180, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0);
LimelightHelpers.setCameraPose_RobotSpace(“limelight-gcc”, -0.318, 0.177, 0.29, 0, 6, 180);
}
}
}

We call this everytime we zero the robot heading- it seems like setting the robot orientation through LL Helpers based on alliance rather than having to set our yaw differently on the red alliance did the trick for us
